newsitem.title: USA: ABC/Money consumer comfort index unchanged at -11.
newsitem.headline: ABC/Money consumer comfort index unchanged at -11.

text.p: The Money Magazine/ABC News consumer comfort index remained unchanged at -11 in the week ended August 18.
"Americans gained some faith in their finances but lost some in the economy," said a report released with the index.

The survey, this time with 1,044 respondents, polls consumers nationwide about the national economy, their own finances and their willingness to spend money. The poll has a margin of error of plus/minus 3.5 percent.
Thirty-nine percent of respondents rated the economy positively, lowering the poll's economic index two points to -22.
Fifty-eight percent rated their own finances highly, and 36 percent said now is a good time to spend.

In a separate question, 25 percent of 486 likely voters said Presidential candidate Bob Dole's 15 percent tax cut proposal made them more likely to vote for him in November. Thirty-six percent said it makes them less likely to vote for Dole, and 28 percent said the proposal did not affect their voting plans.
The separate question had an error margin of plus/minus five percent, the report said.
